t: Proverbs 27
Warnings and Instructions
Do*pn not boast about tomorrow, For*ln you do not know what a day may bring forth.
Let*ln another praise you, and not your own mouth; A*ln stranger, and not your own lips.
A*ln stone is heavy and the sand weighty, But*ln the provocation of a fool is heavier than both of them.
Wrath*ln is fierce and anger is a flood, But*ln who can stand before jealousy?
Better*ln is open rebuke Than*ln love that is concealed.
Faithful*ln are the wounds of a friend, But*ln deceitful are the kisses of an enemy.
A*ln sated man loathes honey, But*ln to a famished man any bitter thing is sweet.
Like*ln a bird that wanders from her nest, So*ln is a man who wanders from his home.
Oil*ln and perfume make the heart glad, So*ln a man’s counsel is sweet to his friend.
Do*ln not forsake your own friend or your father’s friend, And*ln do not go to your brother’s house in the day of your calamity; Better*ln is a neighbor who is near than a brother far away.
Be*ln wise, my son, and make my heart glad, That*ln I may reply to him who reproaches me.
A*ln prudent man sees evil and*i hides himself, The*ln naive proceed and*i pay the penalty.
Take*ln his garment when he becomes surety for a stranger; And*ln for an adulterous woman hold him in pledge.
He*ln who blesses his friend with a loud voice early in the morning, It*ln will be reckoned a curse to him.
A*ln constant dripping on a day of steady rain And*ln a contentious woman are alike;
He*ln who would restrain her restrains the wind, And*ln grasps oil with his right hand.
Iron*ln sharpens iron, So*ln one man sharpens another.
He*ln who tends the fig tree will eat its fruit, And*ln he who cares for his master will be honored.
As*ln in water face reflects*i face, So*ln the heart of man reflects*i man.
Sheol*ln and Abaddon are never satisfied, Nor*ln are the eyes of man ever satisfied.
The*ln crucible is for silver and the furnace for gold, And*ln each is*i tested*i by the praise accorded him.
Though*ln you pound a fool in a mortar with a pestle along with crushed grain, Yet*iln his foolishness will not depart from him.
Know*ln well the condition of your flocks, And*iln pay attention to your herds;
For*ln riches are not forever, Nor*ln does a crown endure*i to all generations.
When*iln the grass disappears, the new growth is seen, And*ln the herbs of the mountains are gathered in,
The*ln lambs will*i be*i for your clothing, And*ln the goats will*i bring*i the price of a field,
And*ln there*i will*i be*i goats’ milk enough for your food, For*ln the food of your household, And*ln sustenance for your maidens.
